John McCain, who, you know, we didn't agree on everything, but man, I mean, what about an incredible American hero? Again, strength, strength, right? We know what the former president said about John McCain. I'm not going to repeat it here, but strength. John McCain stood on principle. He stood on a belief in the importance of patriotism, of sacrifice, of what we stand for as a country. And part of what I talked about at a rally last night is, I shared with the folks in the room. I was there on the Senate floor, way into the middle of the night, when it was yet another attempt of the former president to get rid of the Affordable Care Act, which, as we know, has been literally a lifesaver for people, right? What it has done to no longer allow pre-existing conditions to be the reason that an insurance company can't give you assistance, right? And you all may have seen it. I was there on the floor that night, and we were all standing around because whether or not the Affordable Care Act would continue to be relied on one vote, and we were all standing on the floor. And of course, I had voted to keep going, and I say this, and it sounds like it's out of a movie, but this is how I experienced it, on the floor with my colleagues, and the Senate, well, it was late into the night, and in the Senate, you walk onto the Senate floor, and there were these big wooden ornate doors, and those ornate doors opened, and John McCain came out. And he went to the floor, and he said, No, you don't. I said, No, you don't.

description: Harris speaks at campaign event in Scottsdale, Arizona
text: No, you don't take away health care for millions of people. And that is but one example of an individual that we all respect who put country before party in terms of what they thought was right. I am honored to have the endorsement of Jeff Flake, someone I also worked with. Again, putting country before party. And so I say all of that to say that those are examples that are situated right here in this beautiful state of Arizona. A tradition that everyone and all of us, I will say, stand on. And then of course, most recently, what Maricopa did in terms of the clerk refusing to participate in the intention to undo the will of the people who have been in a free and fair election. The people of this state have always shown extraordinary courage to stand up for the principles upon which we as a country were founded. And I thank you for that. I thank you for that. I know we are going to win this election, and it is not going to be easy. There are forces at play that are making us as Americans, and I think call into question certain fundamentals that we have always taken for granted that is part of our pride. Freedom. Freedom. Freedom from the government making decisions about a person's body, a woman's body. Freedom to just be. Freedom over matters of heart and home, I like to say. Fundamental principles around the importance of rule of law. Whether we should actually be concerned and have a question, a legitimate question in an election for president of the United States, the commander in chief of whether they will abide by the oath. But imagine, imagine, that's a legitimate question we are asking. It's not rhetorical. It's a legitimate question we are asking. He who said that he would quote, terminate the Constitution of the United States. He who said he would be a dictator on day one. He who intends to weaponize the Department of Justice against his political enemies. Take away the independence of the Department of Justice and put in place loyalists, fundamental notions about who and what we are as a democracy.

description: Harris speaks at campaign event in Scottsdale, Arizona
text: Are at play in this election. And you all, each of you, have had the courage to say, hey, we may not agree on every single thing. That's also what a democracy looks like. But foundational first principles cannot be in question. Not for the sake of our children, not for the sake of our future and well-being, not for the sake of our standing in the world. And so I tell you all this to just reaffirm that we share not only a concern but a commitment to our country and what's most important. About in a moment of crisis, dare I say, I think this is one, do we stand together as Americans being our first identity and come together around these issues? And I'm going to actually announce, we have press in the room, that I have decided also not only will I have a Republican in my cabinet, but I'm also going to, I was talking to my team about it, I want to create some structure around the following, which is I love good ideas, wherever they come from, I love good ideas. Right? And so part of what I intend to do, Mayor, and put some structure around, is creating a bipartisan council of advisors who can then give feedback on policy as we go forward. Because here's the thing I also understand and feel strongly about. In order for us as America to maintain our status as the strongest democracy in the world, we need a healthy two-party system. We have to have a healthy two-party system. We have to. It's in the best interest of all of us. It's in the best interest of all of us. You know, the way that I like to lead, I bring folks in my office all the time, and they know I don't want any yes people. I want people to come in and, first of all, be prepared. Yeah, no time to waste, but come in and then let's, as I often say, kick the tires on ideas. Because the best ideas will survive those kinds of challenges, and the best ideas will then be most relevant to the American people, most effective to the American people. And so I'm going to create a bipartisan council so we can put some structure around exactly this point and do the work that is important.

description: Harris speaks at campaign event in Scottsdale, Arizona
text: And then I'm just going to close with this. You know, again, I think on the fundamentals, we have more in common than what separates us, including across faiths. So I know there are a lot of members of the LDS community here, and you may or may not know my pastor actually spoke at the 100th birthday of President Nelson. Yeah. Yeah. And I just, and that wasn't a plan as part of this. It just is. And I just think if we think in our lives and in what we know, there's so many examples of that point. We have so much more in common than what separates us, especially on the fundamentals. And so with that, I say that I am committed to all of you to be a president for all Americans and to work as we must together. Again, knowing we have so much more in common than what separates us and on the biggest and most important issues, I think we know that this is a fight that is not against something, as much as it is a fight that is for something. Thank you. God bless you. God bless you. And God bless you, and I will see you. Thank you. Thank you. Yeah.

description: Harris held a rally in Erie, Pennsylvania

කිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිති� කිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිති� කිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිති� කිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිති�

description: Harris held a rally in Erie, Pennsylvania
text: වහින්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න් මිශ්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්� කිරාරින්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්� කිරාන්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්� කිරාන්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්� කිරාන්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්� කිරාන්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්� මිතින්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්� කරන්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්� කරන්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්� කරන්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්� මිතින්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්� මිතින්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්� කිතින්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්� කිතින්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්� කිතින්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්න්� කිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිතිති� description: Harris participated in an interview with The Shade Room
text: President Barack Obama, he was campaigning for you in Pittsburgh before some students at the University of Pittsburgh, which is my alma mater. And he said some things that really ruffled some feathers in the news. He said, it makes me think you aren't just feeling the idea of having a woman as a president. You're coming up with other alternatives and other reasons for that. We have not seen the same kind of energy and turnout in all corners of our neighborhoods and community as we saw when I was running. So when you hear those words, I'm sure you were briefed on the situation. You know, a former Ohio State Senator, Nina Turner, she came out on CNN and said, why are you, you know, putting black men up against the wall and pressuring them into something that possibly, you know, they don't want to do if they want to vote for you or not. So my question to you is, do you think that what President Obama said was the right thing to say? I'm Justin Carter on Brown here in Greenville, North Carolina with the Vice President, Kamala Harris. She's announcing something big, not only for black men, but for all black people. We also talked HBCUs. We talked Beyonce. It's all coming up on a special edition and exclusive CSR news. Vice President Kamala Harris in the building VP, are you with me? I'm with you. So good to see you again, Justin. Thank you. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It feels great. It has been a whirlwind for you. I feel good. You know, listen, we have 23 days as of today until the election, and I am in these streets traveling and talking with folks. We're here in North Carolina. It's very exciting. You know what's exciting for me is like the rally we're about to do this afternoon in states around our country. People by the thousands are packing these rooms, but the thing that I love about it is people of every different kind of background coming together. And there's so much about how I feel about our message and our movement, if you will, that is grounded in certain beliefs, including the fact that the vast majority of us have so much more in common than what separates us. And it's so important to me that over the course of this campaign, we must win. That's our first imperative, no doubt. But that we build up community, right? And coalitions. I think that's so important. One big theme of your campaign has been freedom. Yes. Freedom, right? Yes. Freedom, freedom, I can't live. I'm not going to mess up the words, but I don't want to get sued by Beyonce. And there are a couple of versions that she has, right? So did you call up the queen? Like, how did that work? Well, she absolutely gave me permission to use the song. I love her. And... Have you met her? I have met her, but not since I've been running just now, but I have met her. And she's just very special. Yeah. Talk about freedom and what that means to you, why that song. It's just imperative. It's crucial right now, what's going on in 2024. I think that there is so much about what is at stake that is, frankly, the need for us to fight for the things that we hold dear, that we have always had to fight for, but must continue to fight for if they're going to be in attack. And frankly, just to be very candid with you, I am seeing across our country a full-on attempt by some to attack these hard-won freedoms and rights, right? The freedom to vote. In Georgia, for example, they passed a law making it illegal to give people food and water for standing in line to vote, which the hypocrisy abounds. Whatever happened to love thy neighbor? You look at the freedom to make decisions for a woman to make decisions about her own body and not have her government tell her what to do. The freedom to love who you love openly and with pride. The freedom to just be is under attack in so many places. The freedom to be safe from gun violence, right? And so there is so much about what's at stake in this election that really is about fighting for freedom because the difference between me and my opponent, the former president, Donald Trump, couldn't be more different on so many of these issues. And so I'm so proud and it always just gives me an extra pet because Beyoncé's freedom is my walk on song in all of these rallies. And did you guys share a moment, you and Beyoncé? I mean, you know, what was that conversation like? Well, she and I have, I'll tell you the last time that I saw her was a couple years ago at actually a BT event. And I mean, she's, you know, and her mother, though, I've been seeing a lot of reason because Beyoncé's been on a tour. She's been doing her thing. Tina is so amazing. Woman of the Year, glamour. Yeah. She's very special. She's very special. She's been supporting me for years. And she actually, the last time I talked to her, she was organizing hairstylists and women who have salons and, you know, who are incredible small business owners to get involved around getting out the vote. Speaking of getting out the vote, you guys are on an HBCU tour. Yes, we are. That's amazing. Come on, HU, you know. You know, you know. In fact, I was with a group of incredible distinguished men last night in North Carolina. And we were all, you know, because we, and they were all, you know, there to support my candidacy and to talk about their, their, a lot of them are business owners. But then, you know, we, I'm not going to say we digress, but we definitely got into it about who went to which school. Well, that was my, that's what I was going to ask you. And had a healthy level of disrespect for each other. Well, man, well, this next question might be, you know, a little controversial. So if you didn't go to Howard, is there another school? I can't imagine a world like that. Would you be a spellman? Do you like, would you be a spellman girl? Would you go to Famu? You know, they're very prideful down there in Florida. And they should be. And there was a reason that Howard is called the Mecca. And I'm very proud to be a bison. See, but we all have fun with each other. But you know what? We have fun with each other. Because here's the thing that we know all of us, whether it, I mean, you mentioned all the schools, whether it be spell, spellmen, Famu, all the, the Morehouse, I mean, all, Shaw, all these schools. We have, we have fun banter among us that is absolutely rooted in a collective pride that we share about our HBCU roots, because it is a very special experience. And it is something that gives us a kindred, I think, look on life about, about pride and about the pride in, in the success that we collectively achieve, a knowledge that we collectively stand on very broad shoulders of, of those historic leaders who graduated from each of these schools. And it is actually with that spirit and that sense of family that then we give each other a hard time about which school does what. It's all good fun. It's in good fun. It's good. It's good fun. It's good fun. And obviously we're, we're walking into a week where, you know, you've been talking about really encouraging black men specifically to get out and vote. And I do want to talk about the numbers. I crunched some numbers at three o'clock this morning. Okay. Okay. There was a poll on Saturday. It said that almost 80% of likely black voters would vote for you if the election were held today. In 2020, though, it was 90% of black voters overall. That was from the New York Times and Santa College. And then in 2016, you know, they also had a poll, the Pew Research Center. They said 81% of black men voted for Hillary Clinton, 14% voted for Trump. In 2020, though, that number jumped 6%. So 87% of black men voted for Biden, 12% voted for Trump in 2020. So when you hear those numbers and you're seeing, you know, in the polls and you're seeing black men aren't as, quote, excited or fired up for you, how do you respond to that? Well, that's not my experience. Okay. One, that's not my experience. Two, Election Day has not arrived yet. Okay. And the third point that is probably the most important point is this. You know, when journalists ask me this question, I often will say to them that, you know, let's be clear that your underlying premise is not an assumption that I'm supposed to have black men in my back pocket in terms of their vote and that I should be, I should be taking that for granted because I don't. Black men are no different from anybody else. They expect that you have to earn their vote. And that's why I'm out here doing the work that I'm doing about talking with folks, listening with folks, because I'm running for president in the United States and it is incumbent on me to earn the support. And that is why I'm talking with folks about the work that I have done in my career, whether it be in particular as vice president, what I've done to put more billions of dollars actually into community banks to increase access to capital for small business owners. Even before I was running for president, I convened a bunch of black small business owners, all who were men, and I purposely convened them to, I brought them into my ceremonial office at the White House to have a meeting about what their needs are and to make sure that they have the information about what's available to them in terms of financing capital and access to capital, support for what they want to do in terms of building or growing their business. So that's the kind of work I will continue to do. But here's the other thing that I think is equally important is pointing out that there are two very different visions for our nation that are being presented to voters right now. On the one side you've got Donald Trump, who wants to take us backward. Donald Trump, who let's not forget when he was renting his apartments and his property, refused to rent to black families. Donald Trump, who as it relates to five young black men, they were actually teenagers and Latinos. The Central Park Five, he took out a full page ad in the New York Times calling for their execution. They were innocent. Donald Trump, who referred to the first black president and suggested, remember the birtherism lies, that he couldn't have been born in the United States. Donald Trump, who in his project 2025, you know that the various things that would happen would include allowing it or making it easier for companies to not give workers overtime pay. We cap the cost of prescription medication at $2,000 a year for seniors and cap the cost of insulin at $35 for our seniors. That's our grandparents. Our parents. Black folks are 60% more likely to be diagnosed with diabetes. His plan would eliminate that cap. So part of the reason that I am out here talking with folks, listening to folks is to make sure that I am communicating and letting them know about the real contrast that is being presented. Because my bottom line is this. I know the power that people have to make a difference. And I respect that power. And I am out here doing the work of earning then the vote so that we can get to the job of continuing to move forward. And for me, that is about pushing for an opportunity economy, which is about tapping into the ambitions and the aspirations of folks and doing the work of investing in community, investing in industries, strengthening our economy, and giving people dignity in the process. Now you have a friend. His name is Barack Hussein Obama. You know him? I do know him. I do. He recently in Pittsburgh. President. President. President. Let's get it right. President Barack Obama. He was campaigning for you in Pittsburgh before some students at the University of Pittsburgh, which is my alma mater. And he said some things that really ruffled some feathers in the news. He said, it makes me think you aren't just feeling the idea of having a woman as a president. You're coming up with other alternatives and other reasons for that. We have not seen the same kind of energy and turnout in all corners of our neighborhoods and community as we saw when I was running. So when you hear those words, I'm sure you were briefed on the situation. You know, a former Ohio State Senator, Nina Turner, she came out on CNN and said, why are you, you know, putting black men up against the wall and pressuring them into something that possibly, you know, they don't want to do if they want to vote for you or not. So my question to you is, do you think that what President Obama said was the right thing to say? Let me tell you, I am very proud to have the support of President Obama and that he is out traveling to talk with voters about what is at stake in this election. I'm very proud to have his support. What is also important is one, to understand, like as I said, I intend to earn the vote of everyone, including black men. Two, pay attention to everything that President Obama talked about because he also talked about at length the danger of Donald Trump, the danger of Donald Trump in terms of somebody who has said that they would weaponize the Department of Justice against his political enemies, somebody who has referred to black immigrants in Springfield, Ohio, legal immigrants as though they would eat their pets, constantly perpetuating tropes. Remember he who, Donald Trump, who said in Charlottesville, they're good people on each side. So I think it's really important to focus on the stakes of this election and there are two choices, two choices. And I ask everyone to look at the background, look at the work, look at the words to have a sense of how you then choose to use the power of your vote on election day. But there is a very big difference between Donald Trump and how I will be President of the United States and I cannot impress upon people enough that this is somebody, Donald Trump, who intends to take us backward. Look, this man won't even debate me a second time. He won't even debate me a second time. He didn't do the 60 minutes interview, which I believe every presidential candidate for President of the United States has done. He will not take up the important responsibility that every presidential candidate has done of showing their medical records. Okay? Which I have done. Of course I've done it. I have done that. I have challenged him to another debate. I have given up my medical records. I did the 60 minutes interview and one has to ask, what is Donald Trump trying to hide? What is his staff and his team trying to keep from you? And it may be the fact that like the people who work closest with him, his chief of staff in the White House, his national security advisor, his secretaries of defense, recently we got the report about General Mark Milley, who all in some have basically said Donald Trump is unfit to be President of the United States and is a danger. And there are many who are believing that all of this points to an individual who is also quite unstable and unfit to be President of the United States. Those are the stakes at play in this election. One more thing I want to ask you before you go and I think it's the fun part. I want to ask you about your plan for black men. Yes. It's something huge that you have just released this week. We're talking about a million, one million loans that are fully forgivable up to $20,000 to black entrepreneurs, men and women, correct? Expanding access to bank accounts, expanding the child tax credit, many things that you're doing. Housing, lowering rent, making it affordable to buy a house for first time home buyers. Talk to me about this plan just in summary and how this will impact not only black men, but all black people. So look, I grew up in the middle class. My mother worked hard. She saved up. And by the time I was a teenager, she was able to buy our first home. I will never forget where I came from. Okay. By the way, my opponent, Donald Trump, was handed $400 million basically on a silver platter and filed for bankruptcy six times. So just keep that in mind about who's coming from where. I know the ambitions, the aspirations, the incredible work ethic that exists in our community. I know the dreams that exist, but not everyone has started out on the same base in terms of being able to realize their goals and their dreams. So my plan is to build what I call an opportunity economy, which means giving people an opportunity to actually achieve those ambitions, those goals and those dreams. So for example, housing is too expensive. The American dream is something that previous generations kind of count on, but no more. So one part of the problem is that we have a supply issue in terms of housing supply. My plan includes working with developers to do what we, and home builders, to create incentives for them to build 3 million new homes by the end of my first term. The second part, which is equally important, if not more, is to give people a first time home buyers a $25,000 down payment assistance. Because what you and I know is a lot of folks want to be a homeowner, but they don't come from money. They don't come from some families that can necessarily pass on a home or give them the equity out of their home to help them with the down payment. $25,000 down payment assistance just helps people get their foot in the door to then save up to cover more. $6,000 child tax credit. I'm expanding the child tax credit to $6,000 for young families so that in the first year of their child's life they have the resources they need to buy a crib, a car seat, clothes, knowing that all parents have a natural desire to parent their children well, but not all parents have the resources to be able to do that. Opportunity. Small businesses. My second mother, our second mother who helped raise us, was a small business owner. I know who our small business owners are. For our communities, they are part of the cultural, economic, civic fabric of our community. They hold the strength of hiring locally, mentoring all that. So I'm going to change so that the tax deduction for a startup small business, change it from what it is, it's $5,000, nobody can start a small business, $5,000 to $50,000, and include in that knowing that a lot of startup businesses then have overhead around, for example, what they need to do to buy equipment for those who are startup and don't have the connections historically, a $20,000 forgivable loan for them to be able, for example, to pay to set up a really good website so that their business could then thrive. Do you think that it might intersect with PPP loans and how some people were involved with that, the PPP loans and fraud and all of that? Fraud. We've done a career prosecuting people for fraud. So we will take care of the abuses. But that's not a reason to not give people an opportunity to thrive. You know, I think there is a real misconception that people just and only their highest aspiration is to have a job. That's not where I come from in terms of how I think of it. The baseline should be everybody has a job. What we should be doing is creating incentives for people to be able to build wealth and build intergenerational wealth. But again, knowing that not everybody starts out on the same base, but when you give them a little bit to just compete, they will work around the clock, good ideas, innovative ideas, and when they have just that little bit extra, it gives them what they need to actually get in there and compete and thrive. That's the theory behind the $20,000 forgivable loan for people at a certain threshold. To just give them the resources, like I said, to start up a website, to buy the equipment they need depending on the kind of business that they're creating so that that's not the barrier to what otherwise is going to be their incredible work ethic and hustle to actually make a success out of their smart idea that actually has relevance to the community. Wow. We are watching. Thank you so much, Vice President Connolly Harris for joining us. It's so important that you're here talking with us. Black media is so important. Of course, always, always.

And he said some things that really ruffled some feathers in the news. He said, it makes me think you aren't just feeling the idea of having a woman as a president. You're coming up with other alternatives and other reasons for that. So when you hear those words, I'm sure you were briefed on the situation. You know, a former Ohio State Senator, Nina Turner, she came out on CNN and said, why are you, you know, putting black men up against the wall and pressuring them into something that possibly, you know, they don't want to do if they want to vote for you or not. So my question to you is, do you think that what President Obama said was the right thing to say? I'm Justin Carter on Brown here in Greenville, North Carolina with the Vice President, Kamala Harris. She's announcing something big, not only for black men, but for all black people. We also talked HBCUs. We talked Beyonce. It's all coming up on a special edition and exclusive CSR news. Vice President Kamala Harris in the building VP, are you with me? I'm with you. So good to see you again, Justin. Thank you. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It's been so long. It feels great. It has been a whirlwind for you. I feel good. You know, listen, we have 23 days as of today until the election, and I am in these streets traveling and talking with folks.

description: Harris participated in an interview with The Shade Room
text: We're here in North Carolina. It's very exciting. You know what's exciting for me is like the rally we're about to do this afternoon in states around our country. People by the thousands are packing these rooms, but the thing that I love about it is people of every different kind of background coming together. And there's so much about how I feel about our message and our movement, if you will, that is grounded in certain beliefs, including the fact that the vast majority of us have so much more in common than what separates us. And it's so important to me that over the course of this campaign, we must win. That's our first imperative, no doubt. But that we build up community, right? And coalitions. I think that's so important. One big theme of your campaign has been freedom. Yes. Freedom, right? Yes. Freedom, freedom, I can't live. I'm not going to mess up the words, but I don't want to get sued by Beyonce. And there are a couple of versions that she has, right? So did you call up the queen? Like, how did that work? Well, she absolutely gave me permission to use the song. I love her. And.. Have you met her? I have met her, but not since I've been running just now, but I have met her. And she's just very special. Yeah. Talk about freedom and what that means to you, why that song. It's just imperative. It's crucial right now, what's going on in 2024. I think that there is so much about what is at stake that is, frankly, the need for us to fight for the things that we hold dear, that we have always had to fight for, but must continue to fight for if they're going to be in attack. And frankly, just to be very candid with you, I am seeing across our country a full-on attempt by some to attack these hard-won freedoms and rights, right? The freedom to vote. In Georgia, for example, they passed a law making it illegal to give people food and water for standing in line to vote, which the hypocrisy abounds. Whatever happened to love thy neighbor? You look at the freedom to make decisions for a woman to make decisions about her own body and not have her government tell her what to do.

description: Harris participated in an interview with The Shade Room
text: The freedom to love who you love openly and with pride. The freedom to just be is under attack in so many places. The freedom to be safe from gun violence, right? And so there is so much about what's at stake in this election that really is about fighting for freedom because the difference between me and my opponent, the former president, Donald Trump, couldn't be more different on so many of these issues. And so I'm so proud and it always just gives me an extra pet because Beyoncé's freedom is my walk on song in all of these rallies. And did you guys share a moment, you and Beyoncé? I mean, you know, what was that conversation like? Well, she and I have, I'll tell you the last time that I saw her was a couple years ago at actually a BT event. And I mean, she's, you know, and her mother, though, I've been seeing a lot of reason because Beyoncé's been on a tour. She's been doing her thing. Tina is so amazing. Woman of the Year, glamour. Yeah. She's very special. She's very special. She's been supporting me for years. And she actually, the last time I talked to her, she was organizing hairstylists and women who have salons and, you know, who are incredible small business owners to get involved around getting out the vote. Speaking of getting out the vote, you guys are on an HBCU tour. Yes, we are. That's amazing. Come on, HU, you know. You know, you know. In fact, I was with a group of incredible distinguished men last night in North Carolina. And we were all, you know, because we, and they were all, you know, there to support my candidacy and to talk about their, their, a lot of them are business owners. But then, you know, we, I'm not going to say we digress, but we definitely got into it about who went to which school. Well, that was my, that's what I was going to ask you. And had a healthy level of disrespect for each other. Well, man, well, this next question might be, you know, a little controversial. So if you didn't go to Howard, is there another school? I can't imagine a world like that.

description: Harris participated in an interview with The Shade Room
text: Would you be a spellman? Do you like, would you be a spellman girl? Would you go to Famu? You know, they're very prideful down there in Florida. And they should be. And there was a reason that Howard is called the Mecca. And I'm very proud to be a bison. See, but we all have fun with each other. But you know what? We have fun with each other. Because here's the thing that we know all of us, whether it, I mean, you mentioned all the schools, whether it be spell, spellmen, Famu, all the, the Morehouse, I mean, all, Shaw, all these schools. We have, we have fun banter among us that is absolutely rooted in a collective pride that we share about our HBCU roots, because it is a very special experience. And it is something that gives us a kindred, I think, look on life about, about pride and about the pride in, in the success that we collectively achieve, a knowledge that we collectively stand on very broad shoulders of, of those historic leaders who graduated from each of these schools. And it is actually with that spirit and that sense of family that then we give each other a hard time about which school does what. It's all good fun. It's in good fun. It's good. It's good fun. It's good fun. And obviously we're, we're walking into a week where, you know, you've been talking about really encouraging black men specifically to get out and vote. And I do want to talk about the numbers. I crunched some numbers at three o'clock this morning. Okay. Okay. There was a poll on Saturday. It said that almost 80% of likely black voters would vote for you if the election were held today. In 2020, though, it was 90% of black voters overall. That was from the New York Times and Santa College. And then in 2016, you know, they also had a poll, the Pew Research Center. They said 81% of black men voted for Hillary Clinton, 14% voted for Trump. In 2020, though, that number jumped 6%. So 87% of black men voted for Biden, 12% voted for Trump in 2020. So when you hear those numbers and you're seeing, you know, in the polls and you're seeing black men aren't as, quote, excited or fired up for you, how do you respond to that? Well, that's not my experience.

description: Harris participated in an interview with The Shade Room
text: Okay. One, that's not my experience. Two, Election Day has not arrived yet. Okay. And the third point that is probably the most important point is this. You know, when journalists ask me this question, I often will say to them that, you know, let's be clear that your underlying premise is not an assumption that I'm supposed to have black men in my back pocket in terms of their vote and that I should be, I should be taking that for granted because I don't. Black men are no different from anybody else. They expect that you have to earn their vote. And that's why I'm out here doing the work that I'm doing about talking with folks, listening with folks, because I'm running for president in the United States and it is incumbent on me to earn the support. And that is why I'm talking with folks about the work that I have done in my career, whether it be in particular as vice president, what I've done to put more billions of dollars actually into community banks to increase access to capital for small business owners. Even before I was running for president, I convened a bunch of black small business owners, all who were men, and I purposely convened them to, I brought them into my ceremonial office at the White House to have a meeting about what their needs are and to make sure that they have the information about what's available to them in terms of financing capital and access to capital, support for what they want to do in terms of building or growing their business. So that's the kind of work I will continue to do. But here's the other thing that I think is equally important is pointing out that there are two very different visions for our nation that are being presented to voters right now. On the one side you've got Donald Trump, who wants to take us backward. Donald Trump, who let's not forget when he was renting his apartments and his property, refused to rent to black families. Donald Trump, who as it relates to five young black men, they were actually teenagers and Latinos. The Central Park Five, he took out a full page ad in the New York Times calling for their execution.

description: Harris participated in an interview with The Shade Room
text: They were innocent. Donald Trump, who referred to the first black president and suggested, remember the birtherism lies, that he couldn't have been born in the United States. Donald Trump, who in his project 2025, you know that the various things that would happen would include allowing it or making it easier for companies to not give workers overtime pay. We cap the cost of prescription medication at $2,000 a year for seniors and cap the cost of insulin at $35 for our seniors. That's our grandparents. Our parents. Black folks are 60% more likely to be diagnosed with diabetes. His plan would eliminate that cap. So part of the reason that I am out here talking with folks, listening to folks is to make sure that I am communicating and letting them know about the real contrast that is being presented. Because my bottom line is this. I know the power that people have to make a difference. And I respect that power. And I am out here doing the work of earning then the vote so that we can get to the job of continuing to move forward. And for me, that is about pushing for an opportunity economy, which is about tapping into the ambitions and the aspirations of folks and doing the work of investing in community, investing in industries, strengthening our economy, and giving people dignity in the process. Now you have a friend. His name is Barack Hussein Obama. You know him? I do know him. I do. He recently in Pittsburgh. President. President. President. Let's get it right. President Barack Obama. He was campaigning for you in Pittsburgh before some students at the University of Pittsburgh, which is my alma mater. And he said some things that really ruffled some feathers in the news. He said, it makes me think you aren't just feeling the idea of having a woman as a president. You're coming up with other alternatives and other reasons for that. We have not seen the same kind of energy and turnout in all corners of our neighborhoods and community as we saw when I was running. So when you hear those words, I'm sure you were briefed on the situation.

description: Harris participated in an interview with The Shade Room
text: You know, a former Ohio State Senator, Nina Turner, she came out on CNN and said, why are you, you know, putting black men up against the wall and pressuring them into something that possibly, you know, they don't want to do if they want to vote for you or not. So my question to you is, do you think that what President Obama said was the right thing to say? Let me tell you, I am very proud to have the support of President Obama and that he is out traveling to talk with voters about what is at stake in this election. I'm very proud to have his support. What is also important is one, to understand, like as I said, I intend to earn the vote of everyone, including black men. Two, pay attention to everything that President Obama talked about because he also talked about at length the danger of Donald Trump, the danger of Donald Trump in terms of somebody who has said that they would weaponize the Department of Justice against his political enemies, somebody who has referred to black immigrants in Springfield, Ohio, legal immigrants as though they would eat their pets, constantly perpetuating tropes. Remember he who, Donald Trump, who said in Charlottesville, they're good people on each side. So I think it's really important to focus on the stakes of this election and there are two choices, two choices. And I ask everyone to look at the background, look at the work, look at the words to have a sense of how you then choose to use the power of your vote on election day. But there is a very big difference between Donald Trump and how I will be President of the United States and I cannot impress upon people enough that this is somebody, Donald Trump, who intends to take us backward. Look, this man won't even debate me a second time. He won't even debate me a second time. He didn't do the 60 minutes interview, which I believe every presidential candidate for President of the United States has done. He will not take up the important responsibility that every presidential candidate has done of showing their medical records.

description: Harris participated in an interview with The Shade Room
text: Okay? Which I have done. Of course I've done it. I have done that. I have challenged him to another debate. I have given up my medical records. I did the 60 minutes interview and one has to ask, what is Donald Trump trying to hide? What is his staff and his team trying to keep from you? And it may be the fact that like the people who work closest with him, his chief of staff in the White House, his national security advisor, his secretaries of defense, recently we got the report about General Mark Milley, who all in some have basically said Donald Trump is unfit to be President of the United States and is a danger. And there are many who are believing that all of this points to an individual who is also quite unstable and unfit to be President of the United States. Those are the stakes at play in this election. One more thing I want to ask you before you go and I think it's the fun part. I want to ask you about your plan for black men. Yes. It's something huge that you have just released this week. We're talking about a million, one million loans that are fully forgivable up to $20,000 to black entrepreneurs, men and women, correct? Expanding access to bank accounts, expanding the child tax credit, many things that you're doing. Housing, lowering rent, making it affordable to buy a house for first time home buyers. Talk to me about this plan just in summary and how this will impact not only black men, but all black people. So look, I grew up in the middle class. My mother worked hard. She saved up. And by the time I was a teenager, she was able to buy our first home. I will never forget where I came from. Okay. By the way, my opponent, Donald Trump, was handed $400 million basically on a silver platter and filed for bankruptcy six times. So just keep that in mind about who's coming from where. I know the ambitions, the aspirations, the incredible work ethic that exists in our community. I know the dreams that exist, but not everyone has started out on the same base in terms of being able to realize their goals and their dreams.

description: Harris participated in an interview with The Shade Room
text: So my plan is to build what I call an opportunity economy, which means giving people an opportunity to actually achieve those ambitions, those goals and those dreams. So for example, housing is too expensive. The American dream is something that previous generations kind of count on, but no more. So one part of the problem is that we have a supply issue in terms of housing supply. My plan includes working with developers to do what we, and home builders, to create incentives for them to build 3 million new homes by the end of my first term. The second part, which is equally important, if not more, is to give people a first time home buyers a $25,000 down payment assistance. Because what you and I know is a lot of folks want to be a homeowner, but they don't come from money. They don't come from some families that can necessarily pass on a home or give them the equity out of their home to help them with the down payment. $25,000 down payment assistance just helps people get their foot in the door to then save up to cover more. $6,000 child tax credit. I'm expanding the child tax credit to $6,000 for young families so that in the first year of their child's life they have the resources they need to buy a crib, a car seat, clothes, knowing that all parents have a natural desire to parent their children well, but not all parents have the resources to be able to do that. Opportunity. Small businesses. My second mother, our second mother who helped raise us, was a small business owner. I know who our small business owners are. For our communities, they are part of the cultural, economic, civic fabric of our community. They hold the strength of hiring locally, mentoring all that. So I'm going to change so that the tax deduction for a startup small business, change it from what it is, it's $5,000, nobody can start a small business, $5,000 to $50,000, and include in that knowing that a lot of startup businesses then have overhead around, for example, what they need to do to buy equipment for those who are startup and don't have the connections historically, a $20,000 forgivable loan for them to be able, for example, to pay to set up a really good website so that their business could then thrive.

description: Harris participated in an interview with The Shade Room
text: Do you think that it might intersect with PPP loans and how some people were involved with that, the PPP loans and fraud and all of that? Fraud. We've done a career prosecuting people for fraud. So we will take care of the abuses. But that's not a reason to not give people an opportunity to thrive. You know, I think there is a real misconception that people just and only their highest aspiration is to have a job. That's not where I come from in terms of how I think of it. The baseline should be everybody has a job. What we should be doing is creating incentives for people to be able to build wealth and build intergenerational wealth. But again, knowing that not everybody starts out on the same base, but when you give them a little bit to just compete, they will work around the clock, good ideas, innovative ideas, and when they have just that little bit extra, it gives them what they need to actually get in there and compete and thrive. That's the theory behind the $20,000 forgivable loan for people at a certain threshold. To just give them the resources, like I said, to start up a website, to buy the equipment they need depending on the kind of business that they're creating so that that's not the barrier to what otherwise is going to be their incredible work ethic and hustle to actually make a success out of their smart idea that actually has relevance to the community. Wow. We are watching. Thank you so much, Vice President Connolly Harris for joining us. It's so important that you're here talking with us. Black media is so important. Of course, always, always.

description: Harris held a rally in Washington Crossing, Pennsylvania with former U.S. Rep. Adam Kinzinger
text: Hello everybody. I am former Republican Congressman Jim Greenwood. I want to welcome you all to Washington Crossing, Bucks County. This is the place where on Christmas Day in 1776, George Washington and 2400 American Patriots crossed the treacherously ice-filled Delaware River back there in a blinding snowstorm and marched 10 miles to Trenton to launch a surprise attack on the Hessian garrison. It was the Continental Army's first major victory of the war and a much needed boost to the morale, inspiring more men to join the Continental Army and enabling the creation of the greatest democracy the world has ever known. So we are here today because we know that whether the United States of America will remain the world's greatest democracy now depends on whether the world's greatest democracy will elect Kamala Harris as the next president of the United States of America. Now I have had the honor to represent this community in the Pennsylvania House and Senate for 12 years and the US Congress for 12 years. I am a lifelong Republican. I noticed when I put my socks on they have elephants on them this morning. And I have supported every Republican nominee for president from Richard Nixon to Mitt Romney. And then along came Donald Trump. For me, as I think it should be for every American, the first threshold for supporting a candidate for public office is not party or policy, but fitness for office. And Donald Trump is utterly and unequivocally unfit for office. Now, I am not a psychiatrist, but I have listened to psychiatrists and they say that Donald Trump is a malignant narcissist and a pathological liar. Even George Santos couldn't keep up with him. Trump cares only about himself and his ambition. He has lied about losing the 2020 election for four years. He summoned his mob to Washington on January 6th and he sat in the White House watching on television as his thugs brutalized law enforcement officers and threatened members of Congress and the vice president for three hours and he did nothing to stop the carnage. Nothing could undermine our democracy more than for hundreds of millions of Americans to believe that our elections are rigged. Never in American history has so many cabinet members, chiefs of staff, military leaders, close associates, and even the vice president himself judged a president to be so dangerous and unfit for office. Now, I am proud to chair Pennsylvania Republicans for Harris-Waltz. And I do so along with my co-chair, Ann Womble, the former chair of the Republican Committee of Lancaster County. Are you here somewhere, Ann? She's probably out canvassing or something. We are not supporting Kamala Harris only because Trump is so grotesquely unfit for office. We support Kamala Harris because she is everything Donald Trump is not. For all of her career, she's been an honest, honorable, and ethical public servant. Kamala Harris is a protector of women and of men and of children. She is authentic, compassionate, serious, wise, and good. She's smarter than Trump, stronger than Trump, tougher than Trump, and a much better dancer than Trump. Republicans and independents across the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and across America are choosing country over party to ensure Donald Trump never steps foot inside the Oval Office again. We're traveling the Commonwealth to mobilize Republican voters and make sure they understand the gravity and the stakes in this election. We want a president with common sense and decency, and that is Kamala Harris. As the vice president often says herself, it's clear we have so much more in common as Americans than what separates us. Standing up for our neighbors, hope for our future, love of country. Pennsylvania is the birthplace of American democracy, and the keystone state will be key to preserving our democracy. We cannot, we will not allow Donald Trump to destroy our democracy, and we will proudly elect Kamala Harris, president of our nation. We Republicans in Pennsylvania are not alone. More than 30 former Republican members of Congress have joined to put country first and endorse Kamala Harris. Several are with us today, and it is my pleasure to recognize former Republican members of Congress, Mickey Edwards of California, Barbara Comstack of Virginia, Joe Walsh of Illinois, Chris Shays of Connecticut, Charles Dejeu of Hawaii, and John LeBoudlais of New York, and Denver Riggleman of Virginia, and David Trott of Michigan, and a real American hero from whom we will soon hear Adam Kinziger. Never clap, the wind's blowing. Others will soon announce their support, and there are many other former Republican members of Congress who have told us that they do not support Kamala, and they will vote, I mean Trump, and they will vote for President Harris, but fear so saying publicly, and that is a shame. So with that, I'm going to wait for the introduction of another real American hero, Jeff Duncan. Please welcome former Lieutenant Governor Jeff Duncan. Good afternoon. It's great to be back in the Keystone State. Little kept secret, this is actually the state I was born in in western Pennsylvania, so I've been spending a lot of time visiting relatives back in the Keystone State. So why in the world is a former Republican Lieutenant Governor from Georgia in Pennsylvania campaigning for a Democratic candidate for President Kamala Harris? It's a very, very simple answer for me, because I care more about the future of this country than I care about the future of Donald Trump. If us Republicans are being intellectually honest with each other, we wouldn't trust Donald Trump to run a lemonade stand, and almost everyone who's ever gotten close to Donald Trump has regretted it. Friends, business partners, cabinet members, former White House staff, generals, everybody seems to regret it. This guy is the ultimate boat anchor around Republicans next, and we know it. This election no doubt is going to be close, and every vote is going to count, especially right here in Pennsylvania, and especially amongst the patriotic Republicans that are willing to put country over party. Let me take a second to set some perspective on how important this election actually is. The future of a free and sovereign Ukraine is on the ballot in November. The future of NATO is on the ballot in November. Whether or not every family in America pays $4,000 in an annual Trump tax increase is on the ballot in November. And last but not least, the future of our country's delicate democracy is on the ballot in November. Us levelheader Republicans are sick and tired of making excuses for Donald Trump everywhere we go, church, neighborhoods, even at our own kitchen tables. It's time for us common sense Republicans to do a little house cleaning and dump Donald Trump. I get asked this question all the time, is it enough for me just to not vote for Donald Trump if I'm a Republican? Can I just skip them on the ballot? And my answer is no, that simply just makes a point that you don't like Donald Trump. We need to make a difference and beat Donald Trump. If you're a Republican and you vote for Kamala Harris in 2024, it doesn't make you a Democrat, it simply makes you a patriot. I've got three great reasons why a Republican should vote for Kamala Harris. First, Donald Trump's been a fake Republican for eight years. He spent eight trillion dollars we didn't have just to simply buy votes. He botched COVID from top to bottom. He'd only built 2% of a border wall that he promised he would build. And worst of all, he became best friends with Vladimir Putin. Donald Trump is the original Rhino in my book. Second of all, Donald Trump is a direct threat to democracy. I had a front row seat in Georgia and watched his willingness to lie, cheat, and steal to try to stay in power in 2020. There's nothing he's not willing to do or say to remain in power, including the tragic events on January 6th. It's important to recognize that he continues to be a threat to democracy. With all the seeds of doubt, he continues to plant around our country. He will be recognized in history as a wannabe dictator, not a former president. Third and most importantly, Kamala Harris will be a better president of the United States than Donald Trump ever will be. She will be the steady hand that this country so desperately needs. She will bring her prosecutor mindset to the Oval Office and be able to see the difference between good and evil. Kamala Harris will continue to focus on the middle class, not pander to them like Donald Trump does. Nothing says middle class more than a small business, whether you own it or work for it. And her dedication to a $50,000 startup tax deduction is huge and will be a catalyst for the American dream for families all over our country. Here's the biggest reason why we should support Kamala Harris as Republicans, because we will never go to bed worrying about where she stands on democracy. We will never go to bed worrying about where she stands on democracy every time we go to bed with Donald Trump in the Oval Office. We should all be concerned about our democracy. We might disagree with her policies, but we will not disagree on democracy. Now look, let's just talk one on one here. Nobody likes hanging out with a liar, right? The last thing you want is a liar is a neighbor, a business partner, you especially don't want a liar as a spouse. We certainly don't want a liar as the president. In our family, we've got a motto, doing the right thing will never be the wrong thing. And so I encourage all my Republican friends, you know the right thing to do. Now have the courage to vote for Kamala Harris in November. It's my honor now to bring to the stage a great friend of mine that's on the same journey who's willing to put country over party, Olivia Troy, former Homeland Security Advisor to Vice President Mike Pence. Thank you and God bless the great state of Pennsylvania. Please welcome former Homeland Security Advisor, Olivia Troy. Thank you. It's great to be with you all today. I actually went to college in Pennsylvania, so it's so great to be back in this beautiful state. So I know you know this, I'm Olivia Troy, I'm a lifelong Republican. I started my career at the Republican National Committee. I served under George W. Bush and then I served as a national security official under Donald Trump. As an official in Trump's administration, I witnessed firsthand his disregard for the American people and his disregard to the rule of law. I had a front row seat to the damage Trump created in his first term and I can confidently and without any hesitation say that he is too dangerous to get anywhere near the Oval Office again. Trump has never cared about making our country safer and I want to be clear that it pains me to say this about someone who served as president of the United States because like many of my colleagues and fellow Americans, I hold the office of the president in very high regard. Donald Trump's North Star is Donald Trump and we saw that when he killed the toughest bipartisan border bill in decades all because he wanted to run on a problem instead of fixing it. That bill which Vice President Kamala Harris supports would have hired more border agents delivered new resources to stop the flow of fentanyl and solved a problem. But Donald Trump stepped in and he stopped it and it's tracks so that he could use it for his own political benefit. He doesn't care about solutions. He cares about power. Power over our daily lives. Power over our future. Power over women. Trump even went as far as saying recently that he'll protect women. Yeah, let me be clear those are his words not mine because I would never in a million years call Trump a protector let alone a protector of women. Do you know many of the women who've been around Donald Trump would agree with me? We all have our own stories and you know what else? American women agree with me because we've watched him rip away our reproductive freedom and we've heard him brag about it over and over again ever since. What's more? We know that it's devastating as Trump's legacy is a second term would be far worse. Trump's project 2025 agenda would ban abortion in every state with or without the help of Congress. It would restrict access to contraception and threaten IVF. So while Trump runs around telling women he'll be our protector, we know the truth. He won't protect our democracy. He won't protect our economy. And he certainly won't protect our healthcare. And he sure as hell won't protect our freedoms. We need a leader who wants to solve problems who will work across the aisle and get things done for the American people. That's why as a lifelong Republican I'll be casting my ballot for Vice President Kamala Harris. I don't have to agree with everything but I know that she will protect our democracy and our fundamental freedoms. She'll be a president for all Americans. Donald Trump will be a president for one person and one person only. Himself. So I thank you all for being here today. Thank you for being part of this growing coalition. It's together that we're going to stand together. They don't get to bully us. They don't get to intimidate us. There are more of us than them. Remember this. Hey, what's going on? What a beautiful day. Good afternoon, everybody. How are you? Excellent. Excellent. Well, look, I'm Adam Kinzinger. I'm a Republican and I am proud to be with you here today. You know, the last four years I've taken stands that have put me on the outside of the party. Some have questioned why I've taken the stands that I have and the answer is really simple because we must put country first. We must put our country over our party and like you, I'm putting my country first. And I thank you for being here. You know, as a young man, what drew me to the Republican Party was its ideals of supporting democracy, of standing for the rule of law, and of honoring the Hollywood document that our founding fathers signed right here in this great state, the Constitution of the United States. And as a military guy, I've always respected strength in leadership and Trump is the opposite of that. He's a whiny, weak, small, tiny man who is scared to death. You know, Donald Trump may be running as a Republican, but the truth is he does not share those long held Republican values of supporting democracy, of standing for the rule of law, and of faithfulness to the Constitution. As a Republican, that saddens me. But what gives me hope is that there is a candidate in this race who does hold those values. You know, I know that Kamala Harris shares my allegiance to the rule of law, to the Constitution, and to democracy. Whatever policies we disagree on, pale in comparison to those fundamental matters of principle, of decency, of fidelity to this nation. You know, democracy knows no party. Democracy is a living, breathing ideal that defines us as a nation. It's the bedrock that separates us from tyranny. And when that foundation is fractured, we must stand united to strengthen it. And I, like you, believe that those values are worth defending. And if you think those principles are worth defending, I urge you to make the conservative choice, vote for our bedrock values, and vote for Kamala Harris. God bless you. Thank you. Please welcome Bob and Chris. Hello, everyone. My name is Bob Lang. And my name is Christina Lang. Christina and I live on our family farm that's been in my family since 1896. Five generations have called that place home. We have been Republicans all our lives. We both voted for Donald Trump. I voted for him twice. It made sense. We are Republicans. You vote for the Republican candidate. I should make a note. Christina was ahead of the learning curve. She only voted for him once. I thought he'd fight for people like us, but it's clear Donald Trump doesn't care about helping hardworking people. And he certainly doesn't care about our commonwealth and our Constitution. He only cares about what's good for him. January 6th was the straw that broke the camel's back for me. I watched in horror as what went down. The guy encouraged a violent mob to storm the Capitol, then sat back and did nothing, and attempted to overturn a free and fair election. Just this week, he called for the unleashing of US military on American citizens who he called the enemy within. That is dangerous language. We know that a second Trump term would be much worse than his first. And we deserve better. We deserve a leader who will bring people together and fight for the middle class, not someone who tries to divide us. We also need someone who actually cares about the American people and who will defend our Constitution. And that's why Bob and I are both voting for Kamala Harris. Never in a million years did either of us think that we'd be standing here supporting a Democrat. But we've had enough. We've had enough. And we've also noticed that Kamala is an amazing candidate in so many ways. But it's time to turn the page on Trump and his chaos and the way he divides us as people in this nation. We've got to move forward. We've got to elect someone who is in this fight for the working class people. And not trying to help her rich friends get richer. Or taking revenge on people that have slighted her in any way. We've got to elect someone who will take our commonwealth forward and not backwards. There's more at stake in this election than any other election in my lifetime. And the choice for us and millions of Republicans across the country is simple. It's Kamala Harris. She's charting a new way forward. Forward where costs are lower for folks like us and you. And where our democracy and freedoms are a priority and are protected. And now we are so incredibly honored to introduce our incredible leader. Please join us in welcoming the next president of the United States Vice President Kamala Harris. Pennsylvania. Good afternoon everyone. Good afternoon. Bob and Christina. Thank you so very much for that introduction and for your friendship. And as I've said to all the friends and leaders on the stage with me, we had a chance to speak ahead of time. I thank you all for everything that you are doing and the courage you are showing. You know this is an extraordinary climate right now. And I think we all recognize the courage that you are each showing to speak out so publicly and to put as we are saying because we truly believe a country over power. So thank you all. Can we please applaud Bob and Christina and all of the folks on the stage please. Thank you. Thank you. So if you all have a seat please do sit. Yes. So as I think everyone here knows, we meet in a place that holds a very special meaning for our country. Here on Christmas night, 1776, General George Washington and over 2000 troops crossed the icy Delaware River in darkness. Then marched to Trenton where they surprised an outpost of enemy soldiers and achieved a major victory in the American Revolution. And after we won the war and achieved our independence, delegates from across the nation gathered not far from here in Philadelphia to write and to sign the Constitution of the United States. And we remember and reflect on what that moment was. Knowing that leading up to that, that work to write, to compose the Constitution of the United States, that work was not easy. The founders often disagreed, often quite passionately. But in the end, the Constitution of the United States laid out the foundations of our democracy, including the rule of law, that there would be checks and balances, that we would have free and fair elections, and a peaceful transfer of power. And these principles and traditions have sustained our nation for over two centuries. Sustained because generations of Americans from all backgrounds, from all beliefs, have cherished them, upheld them, and defended them. And now the baton is in our hands. So I am joined today by over 100 Republican leaders from across Pennsylvania and across our country who are supporting my candidacy for president of the United States. And I am deeply honored to have their support. Some served in state houses, some in the United States Congress, some worked for other Republican presidents and presidential nominees, including Mitt Romney, John McCain, George W. Bush, George H. W. Bush, and Ronald Reagan. And some today served in Donald Trump's own administration. We also have with us Republican voters from here in Pennsylvania and beyond who have been active in their Republican parties for years, who have supported Republican candidates up and down the ticket. Now, I say all that to make an obvious point. In a typical election year, you all being here with me might be a bit surprising, dare I say unusual. But not in this election. Not in this election. Because at stake in this race are the Democratic ideals that our founders and generations of Americans before us have fought for. At stake in this election is the Constitution of the United States, it very self. We are here today because we share a core belief that we must put country before party. We chant that with such great pride because we all know we all have so much more in common than what separates us. And at some point in the career of the folks who joined me on stage, one of the other things that we have in common is in our careers, we have each sworn an oath to uphold the Constitution of the United States. And so we know that sacred oath must always be honored and never violated. And that we should expect anyone who seeks the highest office in our land would meet that standard. We here know the Constitution is not a relic from our past, but determines whether we are a country where the people can speak freely and even criticize the president without fear of being thrown in jail or targeted by the military. Where the people can worship as they choose without the government interfering. Where you can vote without fear that your vote will be thrown away. All of this and more depends on whether or not our leaders honor their oaths to the Constitution. I have sworn an oath to uphold the Constitution six times, including as Vice President, as the United States Senator, and as the top law enforcement officer of the largest state in our country. And I have never wavered from upholding that oath. And this is a profound difference between Donald Trump and me. He who violated the oath to uphold the Constitution of the United States and make no mistake, he who, if given the chance, will violate it again. Donald Trump lost the 2020 election. And he refused to accept the will of the people and the results of a free and fair election. He sent a mob, an armed mob, to the United States Capitol where they violently assaulted police officers, law enforcement officials, and threatened the life of his own vice president. And he refused to engage in the peaceful transfer of power. Were it not for the courage and patriotism of Vice President Pence that day, Donald Trump might have actually succeeded in overturning the will of the American people. Let's reflect on that. And now, Donald Trump is telling us how he intends to use power if he is elected again. He has stated that one of the biggest threats America faces is, quote, the enemy from within. The enemy from within. But nowhere that language harkens back to. Understand and let us be clear about what he is saying. He considers any American who doesn't support him or bend to his will to be an enemy to our country. And further, he says that as commander in chief, he would use our military to go after them. Honestly, let that sink in. Use of the American military? To go after American citizens? And we know who he would target first, because he has targeted them and attacked them before. Journalists whose stories he doesn't like. Nonpartisan election officials who refused to cheat by finding extra votes for him. Judges who insist on following the law instead of following him. It is clear Donald Trump is increasingly unstable and unhinged. And he is seeking unchecked power. Consider what his closest advisors have said. His national security advisor, two defense secretaries, his former chief of staff, his own vice president. All have warned America Donald Trump is unfit to serve. Or listen to General Milley. Donald Trump's top general. He has called Trump, and I quote, fascist to the core. And said, quote, no one has ever been as dangerous to this country. So think about that. General Milley served in uniform for more than 40 years, commanding American forces around the world. He has confronted some of America's worst enemies. And he is saying no one has ever been as dangerous to our country as Donald Trump. America must heed this warning because anyone who tramples on our democratic values as Donald Trump has, anyone who has called for the quote termination of the Constitution of the United States as Donald Trump has, must never again stand behind the seal of the President of the United States. Never again. Never again. And to those, and to those who are watching, if you share that view, no matter your party, no matter who you voted for last time, there is a place for you in this campaign. The coalition we have built was ready to turn the page on the chaos and instability of Donald Trump. And I pledge to you to be a president for all Americans. And I take that pledge seriously. I take that pledge quite seriously. So as I've mentioned, many of you know, I spent a career as a prosecutor in law enforcement, and I will tell you, I never asked a victim or a witness, are you a Republican or are you a Democrat? I never asked of anyone who needed help. If anyone who deserved attention, where were they registered and who did they vote for? The only question I ever asked was, are you okay? And that is the kind of president I pledge to you that I will be. That is my pledge to you. Because we have too much to do and too much good work to do to be relegated, to requiring each of us to be in some silo disconnected from each other. There's too much good to be done. And the challenges that we face as a nation require us, if we truly want, to create solutions and strengthen our nation. The approach truly requires that we understand we're all in this together. This is so much more than rhetoric or a campaign. It really is about tapping into the spirit of who we are as Americans. Because we are all in this together. We are all in this together. And so I pledge to be a president who actively works to unite us around our highest aspirations. I pledge to be you, to be a president who is realistic and practical and has common sense and to always fight for the American people. Unlike Donald Trump, who frankly as we have seen, cares more about running on problems than fixing problems. I want to fix problems, which means working across the aisle. It requires working across the aisle. It requires embracing good ideas from wherever they come. That is why I have pledged to appoint a Republican in my cabinet. That is why I have pledged to establish a council on bipartisan solutions to recommend to me common sense solutions to some of the most pressing issues facing our country. Because nobody has a corner on the good ideas. They actually come from many places and one should, especially if they want to be a leader, one should welcome those ideas. And those ideas, which are about in particular strengthening the middle class, securing our border, defending our freedoms, and maintaining our leadership in the world. And all of this is to also say that I believe for America to be the world's strongest democracy, we must have a healthy two-party system. Because it is when we have a healthy two-party system that leaders are then required to debate the merits of policy and to work yes across the aisle regularly and routinely to get things done. And I have experienced firsthand how important and rewarding that kind of bipartisan cooperation can be. So I'll tell you, when I was the United States Senator, I served on the Senate Intelligence Committee. It was actually my favorite committee for a number of reasons, but specifically this. There we dealt with some of the most pressing issues affecting national security. There we would talk about hot spots around the world and what we needed to do to focus on keeping America safe and secure. And to do that, we would review classified information which required us to meet in a secure room. Adam, you know, it's called a skiff. Okay. When we would go in that room, with all due respect, no cameras were allowed. No press. And we would roll up our sleeves and get to work. I'm telling you, senators of both parties would walk in that room, take off their suit jackets, roll up their sleeves, have a cup of coffee on the table. And we would have real conversations. Real conversations. As Americans. Because we understood that what happened in that room, well, the stakes were so high.
